sn2.20:4.1: Standing to one side, the god Anāthapiṇḍika recited these verses in the Buddha’s presence:
sn2.20:5.2: frequented by the Saṅgha of seers,
sn2.20:5.3: where the King of Dhamma stayed:
sn2.20:7.4: and thus be purified in it.
sn2.20:8.3: any mendicant who has gone beyond
sn2.20:9.1: This is what the god Anāthapiṇḍika said.
sn2.20:9.2: Then he bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right side, before vanishing right there.
sn2.20:10.1: Then, when the night had passed, the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
sn2.20:10.2: “Mendicants, tonight, a certain beautiful god, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, came to me,
sn2.20:10.4: and recited these verses in my presence.” The Buddha then repeated the verses in full.
sn2.20:16.1: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha:
sn2.20:16.2: “Sir, that god must surely have been Anāthapiṇḍika.
sn2.20:16.3: For the householder Anāthapiṇḍika had so much confidence in Venerable Sāriputta.”
sn2.20:16.4: “Good, good, Ānanda. You’ve reached the logical conclusion, as far as logic goes.
sn2.20:16.5: For that was indeed the god Anāthapiṇḍika.”
